direct_ad_hominem: Direct ad Hominem (DAH) \ Character Attack Premise: a is a person of bad character. \ Conclusion: a's argument x should not be accepted. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is there any evidence that supports a's argument x? \ CQ2: Is the issue of character relevant in the type of dialogue in which the argument was used?
expert_opinion: Argument From Expert Opinion (AFEO) \ Major Premise: Source E is an expert in subject domain S containing proposition A. \ Minor Premise: E asserts that proposition A is true (false). \ Conclusion: A is true (false). \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is E an expert in the field that A is in? \ CQ2: Is E personally reliable as a source in the domain S? \ CQ3: Is E's assertion about A based on evidence?
ignorance: Argument From Ignorance (AFIG) \ Major Premise: If A were true, then A would be known to be true. \ Minor Premise: It is not the case that A is known to be true. \ Conclusion: Therefore, A is not true \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is A actually not known to be true? \ CQ2: Is there enough evidence to support that A is not true?
inconsistent_commitment: Inconsistent Commitment (IC) \ Initial Commitment Premise: a has claimed or indicated that he is committed to proposition A (generally, or by virtue of what he has said in the past). \ Opposed Commitment Premise: Other evidence in this particular case shows that a is not really committed to A. \ Conclusion: a's commitments are inconsistent \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is there any evidence that shows that a is committed to A? \ CQ2: Has a some conflict of commitments with A?
popular_opinion: Argument From Popular Opinion (AFPO) \ General Acceptance Premise: A is generally accepted as true. \ Presumption Premise: If A is generally accepted as true, that gives a reason in favor of A. \ Conclusion: There is a reason in favor of A. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is there any evidence to support the claim that A is generally accepted as true? \ CQ2: Are there any good reasons for doubting that A is true?
popular_practice: Argument From Popular Practice (AFPP) \ Major Premise: A is a popular practice among those who are familiar with what is acceptable or not in regard to A. \ Minor Premise: If A is a popular practice among those familiar with what is acceptable or not with regard to A, that gives a reason to think that A is acceptable. \ Conclusion: Therefore, A is acceptable in this case. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is actually A accepted by a large majority? \ CQ2: Is A justified because maybe there is a large majority that supports it? \ CQ3: Is accepting A based solely on popular support reasonable?
position_to_know: Argument From Position to Know (AFPK) \ Major Premise: Source a is in position to know about things in a certain subject domain S containing proposition A. \ Minor Premise: a asserts that A is true (false). \ Conclusion: A is true (false). \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is a in position to know whether A is true (false)? \ CQ2: Is a an honest (trustworthy, reliable) source? \ CQ3: Did a assert that A is true (false)?
witness_testimony: Argument From Witness Testimony (AFWT) \ Position to Know Premise: Witness W is in a position to know whether A is true or not. \ Truth Telling Premise: Witness W is telling the truth (as W knows it). \ Statement Premise: Witness W states that A is true (false). \ Conclusion: A may be plausibly taken to be true (false). \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is what the witness W said in A internally consistent? \ CQ2: Is there some kind of bias that can be attributed to the account given by the witness W? \ CQ3: Is the statement A asserted by the witness W plausible?
example: Argument From Example (AFEX) \ Premise: In this particular case, the individual a has property F and also property G. \ Conclusion: Therefore, generally, if x has property F, then it also has property G. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is the proposition claimed in the premise in fact true? \ CQ2: Does the example cited support the generalization it is supposed to be an instance of? \ CQ3: Do special circumstances of the example impair its generalizability?
analogy: Argument From Analogy (AFAN) \ Similarity Premise: Generally, case C1 is similar to case C2. \ Base Premise: A is true (false) in case C1.\ Conclusion: A is true (false) in case C2 \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Are there differences between C1 and C2 that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited? \ CQ2: Is A true (false) in C1? \ CQ3: Is there some other case C3 that is also similar to C1, but in which A is false (true)?
precedent: Argument From Precedent (AFPR) \ Major Premise: Generally, according to the established rule, if x has property F, then x also has property G. \ Minor Premise: In this legitimate case, a has F but does not have G.\ Conclusion: Therefore, an exception to the rule must be recognized, and the rule appropriately modified or qualified. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Does the established rule really apply to this case? \ CQ2: Is the case cited legitimate, or can it be explained as only an apparent violation of the rule? \ CQ3: Can the case cited be dealt with under an already recognized category of exception that does not require a change in the rule?
estalished_rule: Argument From Established Rule (AFRL) \ Major Premise: If carrying out types of actions including A is the established rule for x, then (unless the case is an exception), x must carry out A. \ Minor Premise: Carrying out types of actions including A is the established rule for a. \  Conclusion: Therefore, a must carry out A.\ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \  CQ1: Does the rule require carrying out types of actions that include A as an instance? \ CQ2: Are there other established rules that might conflict with or override this one? \ CQ3: Is this case an exceptional one, that is, could there be extenuating circumstances or an excuse for noncompliance?
verbal_classification: Argument From Verbal Classification (AFVC) \ Individual Premise: a has property F. \ Classification Premise: For all x, if x has property F, then x can be classified as having property G. \ Conclusion: a has property G \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: What evidence is there that a definitely has property F? \ CQ2: Is the verbal classification in the classification premise based merely on an assumption about word usage that is subject to doubt?
waste: Argument From Waste (AFWS) \ Premise 1: If a stops trying to realize A now, all a's previous efforts to realize A will be wasted. \ Premise 2: If all a's previous attempts to realize A are wasted, that would be a bad thing. \ Conclusion: Therefore, a ought to continue trying to realize A. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Is bringing about A possible? \ CQ2: Forgetting past losses that cannot be recouped, should a reassessment of the cost and benefits of trying to bring about A from this point in time to be made?
sunk_costs: Argument From Sunk Costs (AFSC) \ Premise 1: There is a choice at t2 between A and not-A. \ Premise 2: At t2 I am precommitted to A because of what I did or committed myself to at t1. \ Conclusion: Therefore, I should choose A. \ TThese are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Does the pre-commitment at t1 directly influence the decision at t2? \ CQ2: Is it rational to prioritize past investments of t1 over present circumstances in t2 in order to choose A or not-A? \ CQ3: Are there any alternative options beyond A and not-A that should be considered?
threat: Argument From Threat (AFTH) \ Premise 1: If you bring about A, some cited bad consequences, B, will follow. \ Premise 2: I am in position to bring about B. \ Premise 3: I hereby assert that in fact I will see to it that B occurs if you bring about A. \ Conclusion: Therefore, you had better not bring about A. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Are the consequences B truly significant enough to warrant consideration and influence decision-making regarding bringing about A? \ CQ2: Is the assertion that B will occur if A is brought about credible? \ CQ3: Is the speaker truly in a position to bring about B, as claimed in Premise 2?
sign: Argument From Sign (AFSI) \ Specific Premise: A (a finding) is true in this situation. \ General Premise: B is generally indicated as true when its sign, A, is true. \ Conclusion: B is true in this situation. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument: \ CQ1: Does the specific premise (A) accurately represent a finding in this situation? \ CQ2: Does the general premise (B) consistently hold true when the sign A is present? \ CQ3: Are there any additional factors needed to establish the truth of B beyond the presence of A?
cause_to_effect: Argument From Cause to Effect (AFCE) \ Major Premise: Generally, if A occurs, then B will (might) occur. \ Minor Premise: In this case, A occurs (might occur). \ Conclusion: Therefore, in this case, B will (might) occur. \ These are the default critical questions of the scheme aim to evaluate the veracity of the argument:\ CQ1: Is the evidence cited (if there is any) strong enough to warrant the causal generalization? \ CQ2: Are there other causal factors that could interfere with the production of the effect in the given case?
